comment.author: 38197978@N02
comment._content: Yes, pipes; of this basic type, German, or Tyrolian: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/stull17/2636832183/] A long stem, with the bowl separate, and low, on the stem. These look like wood, my guess would be cherry; most pipes of this type that I am familiar with have clay or ceramic bowls. Sander: www.moma.org/collection/browse_results.php?criteria=O%3AA... There is a specific Sander image, of a man leaning against a wall, smoking just such a long-stemmed pipe. Which I cannot find.

comment.author: 59905180@N03
comment._content: Surrealism...

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: Lots of travelers' souvenirs, but not so colonial. The Bengal Tigers are likely from India, but the Pipes are likely Tyrolean, the spurs look like Espuelas Grandes of the type favored by 18th century Spanish conquistadors, the wine jugs on the mantle are greek oinochoe, and the marvelous 6 legged tray table is decidedly Moorish. Throw in a bearskin in front of the hearth and the pair of Arts & Crafts end tables (probably late 19th century) and it's a properly cluttered hodgepodge.

comment.author: 83041814@N00
comment._content: Actually, I think those are probably not tyrolean pipes, but rather opium pipes. Tyrolean pipes were traditionally curved, whereas opium pipes were usually straight, as these are. Opium pipes were also popular souvenirs from the British colonies in Asia, especially Hong Kong, and thus would fit with the general "orientalist" theme of the room.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Great contribution! Considering tagging for hodgepodge...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/thiskidgotmoxie] Definitely think you're onto something with the opium pipes. Have searched all over the interweb, and all opium pipes are excessively long and straight in comparison to "normal" and curvy Tyrolean pipes...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/83041814@N00] Definitely a form of Tyrolean smoker's pipe - a classic and true design of its type. These pipes were used over Southern Germany and Austria but have no opium connection at all. They were standard tobacco pipes for that region.

The stems were usually of cherry wood and did not necessarily come from the same factory that made the porcelain sections. Often, the stems could be turned and made locally, hence the large range of variations. 

Had a closer look at this pic - there appears to be an image of a man wearing a tricorne hat accompanied by text. Would be nice to know which design this was! The pipe in the above pic is one of the higher quality and more expensive types.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] But are Tyrolean pipes not always curvy, as opposed to these straight ones?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
